[blank] X Even Aristotle was catholic enough to maintain that "the many" are better
[blank] judges of poetry than the expert few. IX In the 5th c. their "ethical twist" puts
[blank] them out of court as literary critics. X Plato is the first Greek who
[blank] really graduated in literary criticism. He valued art for its moral effect on
[blank] conduct . . . But he valued it too for its own sake.
[blank] [The artist’s] power is a spiritual magnetism . . . this fascination — a }

[blank] Wonderful creatures, these poets, but out they must go. They endanger the ideals

[blank] . . . What do we want with an imitation of an imitation? And in the Phaedrus —
[blank] where his enthus. for literature is not concealed . . . books are unsatisfactory,
[blank] because you can’t cross-examine them. "They go on saying the same thing
[blank] It is this view that Aristotle combats, finding the answer in
[blank] Plato’s own mouth. It is not the "particulars" of sense that Art
[blank] represents but "universal" Truths,—the inner interpretation of
[blank] the mind . . . So Poetry is not 3 removes fr. truth: it comes nearer
[blank] the truth than any other human process, since it records "not what
[blank] did happen but what would happen." Poetics ch. IX §1
[blank] and disentangles from human incidents the principles on which life works.
[blank] The truth of art is higher than the truth of fact.
